title: Marina Solodkin
text:
Marina Solodkin (, ; 31 May 1952 – 16 March 2013) was an Israeli politician and member of the <a href="Knesset">Knesset</a> for <a href="Yisrael%20BaAliyah">Yisrael BaAliyah</a>, <a href="Likud">Likud</a> and <a href="Kadima">Kadima</a>.
She immigrated to Israel from Russia in the early 1990s and joined the immigrant <a href="Yisrael%20BaAliyah">Yisrael BaAliyah</a> party and entered the <a href="Knesset">Knesset</a> in 1996. She served as a lawmaker until February 2013 when she lost her seat in the elections.
Biography.
Marina Gershman (later Solodkin) was born in Moscow in the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>. Solodkin studied at <a href="Moscow%20State%20University">Moscow State University</a>, where she gained a <a href="doctorate">PhD</a> in economic and social science. She immigrated to Israel in 1991. Solodkin died of a stroke in a hotel room in <a href="Latvia">Latvia</a> on 16 March 2013. She wrote on her Facebook page the Friday before: "In a few hours' time I will take off for Latvia in order to take part in a conference I was invited to by the Latvian Committee against Fascism… Lately, Neo-Nazism is raising its ugly head in Eastern Europe, in the post-Soviet states. We must remain vigilant."
She was survived by her husband and two children. She lived in <a href="Ashkelon">Ashkelon</a>.
Political career.
In Israel, Solodkin joined the Russian-immigrant party, <a href="Yisrael%20BaAliyah">Yisrael BaAliyah</a> led by Soviet dissident <a href="Natan%20Sharansky">Natan Sharansky</a>. She was elected to the Knesset in the <a href="1996%20Israeli%20legislative%20election">1996 elections</a> on the party's list and chaired the committee on the Status of Women. After retaining her seat in the <a href="1999%20Israeli%20legislative%20election">1999 elections</a>, she was appointed Deputy <a href="Immigrant%20Absorption%20Minister%20of%20Israel">Minister of Immigrant Absorption</a>, a post she regained during the <a href="2003%20Israeli%20legislative%20election">16th Knesset</a> after Yisrael BaAliyah had merged into <a href="Likud">Likud</a>.
Shortly before the <a href="2006%20Israeli%20legislative%20election">2006 elections</a> Solodkin resigned from the Knesset in order to join Kadima. She gained 6th place on the party's list and was re-elected. However, in protest at not being appointed a Minister despite her high position on Kadima's list, she was absent from the swearing-in ceremony of the new government. Her absence from the <a href="Cabinet%20of%20Israel">cabinet</a> was unpopular with many Russian immigrants.
She called for foreign agricultural workers to be replaced with <a href="Beta%20Israel">Ethiopian immigrants</a>, and demanded that <a href="Ariel%20Toaff">Ariel Toaff</a> be put on trial for his book about <a href="blood%20libel">blood libel</a>. She has also said that <a href="Ehud%20Olmert">Ehud Olmert</a> should resign over the <a href="2006%20Lebanon%20War">2006 Lebanon War</a>.
She retained her seat in the <a href="2009%20Israeli%20legislative%20election">2009 elections</a> after being placed tenth on the party's list. On 5 December 2012, in the days leading up to the <a href="2013%20Israeli%20legislative%20election">2013 elections</a>, while polls showed Kadima either barely getting into the Knesset or not even passing the threshold, Solodkin announced she would not contest the elections.
